conclusion: Analyzing the Difference in Displacement Between Objects A and B
Let me analyze the motion of the two objects by examining the v-t graph and calculating how their displacements compare over time.
The graph shows velocity (v) vs. time (t) for two objects A and B.
Both curves start at the origin (0,0) and end at the time t₁ on the t-axis.
Object A has a higher velocity curve than object B throughout the interval.
Both objects are moving in the same direction along a straight line.
Recall that displacement is the area under the v-t curve.

premise: Displacement of A = area under curve A from 0 to t; Displacement of B = area under curve B from 0 to t
conclusion: For any time t in the interval [0, t₁], the displacement of object A is greater than the displacement of object B.
Let's define: D_A(t) = displacement of object A at time t; D_B(t) = displacement of object B at time t; ΔD(t) = D_A(t) - D_B(t) = difference in displacement at time t
For this difference to be continuously increasing, we need: d(ΔD)/dt > 0 for all t in [0, t₁]
The rate of change of displacement is simply velocity, so: d(D_A)/dt = v_A(t); d(D_B)/dt = v_B(t); d(ΔD)/dt = v_A(t) - v_B(t)

premise: v_A(t) > v_B(t) for all t in [0, t₁] since curve A is always above curve B
conclusion: d(ΔD)/dt > 0 for all t in [0, t₁], which means ΔD(t) is continuously increasing.

premise: d(ΔD)/dt > 0 for all t in [0, t₁]
conclusion: Yes, the difference in displacement between the two objects is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t₁. This is because the velocity of object A is always greater than the velocity of object B throughout this time interval, meaning that object A is pulling away from object B at all times.
